document.text: years 1914 to 1916. At the same time, these leading growers, through their cooperative efforts in handling the surplus, have caused an increased demand tor that portion of the crop sold over the auction floors which has netted the growers over 75 per cent more than pre-war price. During the four years which the cooperative association has operated, there has been a grad ual decrease in the production ot dark fired tobacco in spite of the comparatively good prices which were being paid. The production for 1922 was ap proximately 49,000,000 pounds for 1923 44,000,000 pounds for 1924 43.000,000 pounds and for 1925 41,000,000 pounds. It is, of course, recognized that weath er conditions had more to do with this decreased production than any other one factor, but there is reason to believe that a cooperative association con trolling a sufficient quantity of the product can gradually con trol production through grad ually lowering prices when pro duction is too high, and grad- uolly increasing prices when production is too low. It may be said that this is just what happens under the auction sys tem, but the objection to this system is that the price fluctua tions are too violent. For in stance, under the auction system a 36,000,000 pound crop of Vir ginia dark fired tobacco in, 1919 sold on the auction floor for an average price of nearly 25c per pound, while the 4, 000,000 pound crop produced in 1920 brought only about 9c per pound, and the 49,000,000 pound cropldence. produced in 1922 brought nearly 20c per pound. There can be no permanent prosperity among farmers as long as we have such violent fluctuations in prices from year to year. In view of these facts, it would seem that cooperation still has much to offer to the tobacco growers and other business men of the Virginia dark fired belt If this much could be accom plished when our farmers know practically nothing about coop erative marketing, is it no logi cal to expect that more can be accomplished during the next five years with our farmers hav ing learned much by practical experience concerning both the limitations and possibilities of cooperation? J. R. Hutcheson.

Pauley, of the West Virginia State Federation of Labor, also urged all national and International unions to Insert clauses in their working agree ments whereby they can render such assistance as is needed by any and 11 crafts when called upon to do so. It asked that all unions arrange the dates of their contracts so that they would expire at the same time. The convention was thrown into confusion when several delegates by objections denied the negro delega tion permission to introduce a resolu tion condemning the mob violence of the Ku Klux Klan, or White Cap, of the South. President Samuel Gompers had great difficulty in restoring order, as nearly  score of delegates Jumped from their seats and demanded the names of the delegates who had ob jected. He declined to give the names. As the confusion increased President Wil- - Ilam Hutcheson, of the United Brother hood of Carpenters and Joiners, arose and said If you want to know who the ob jector isIt is I. Several delegates called his name aloud as the convention proceeded to further business. The resolution also urged that steps be taken to have the Government abolish this unlawful organ known as the Ku Klux Klan or white caps, and that the Federation use Its best endeavors to protect organized labor as represented by the colored work ers.

document.text: Way land Ferguson repre sented the DECA chapter of Appomattox High School at the 33rd Annual Virginia Distribu tive Education Clubs of America S tate Leadership Conference, The SLC was held at the Hotel Roanoke on March 12-14. While attending the .confer ence Wayland joined approxi mately 600 delegates in electing State Officers and in planning work programs for the coming year for local chapters. Contest finalists from twenty-four Vir ginia DCA districts competed for state awards and the chance to represent Virginia at the National Career Development Conference in Chicago. The conference was high lighted Saturday night starting with a buffet dinner. From 8-10 p.m. an awards ceremony to recognize contest winners was hosted by Kevin Reynolds, who has been the featured Vocalist at the Miss America Pageant. After the ceremony an Awards Ball was given and everyone enjoyed dancing and the music by Reynolds and Co. Mr. Jack Hutcheson, Distri butive Education coordinator at ACHS, accompanied Wayland to Roanoke. Mr. Hutcheson served as a chaperone for the State Leadership Conference. Wayland is a senior at Appom attox County High School and employed by Webbs Tire Company. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. William D. Ferguson, Jr. of Oakville.

document.text: Washington, D. C.- The National League baseball picture is not as complicated, this training season, as is the American League picture. In the junior loop there are five teams which might win the flag and a sixth strong one. In the National, Brooklyn com pletely outclassed the competition last year and the question is wheth er there are teams in that circuit which will put up a good light for the pennant this year. ___________ There is this in favor of the challengers first, Brooklyns stars are not youngsters, for the most part. Second, they havent got Johnny Podres, who won the World Series for them. Third, there will be some improvement shown by sev eral competing teams. Fred Hutcheson is new at St. Louis. There he will try to take Stan Musiel, who is only to be a- round so much longer, and the oth er regulars and youngsters, and get the Cardinals back into the flag fight. Chicagos young team, which lead the league a while last year, will probably be stronger. But St. Louis and Chicago finished 7th an d 6th last year. It looks like New York, and Milwaukee will have to provide the keen competition again in 1956. The Phillies and Redlegs, who came in 4th and 5th, may get into the act, but neither looks like a pen nant winner. If Chicago and St. Louis are years away, Brooklyn

The Navy Department received a message from Commander Schroeder at Guam stating that the Filipino prisoners there have a government of their own, with General Pilar as president. Judge Taft took the oath and was formally installed as governor of the Philippine Islands. Governor General Wood, of Cuba, re ported that he is ill with typhoid of a mild type. Gen. Chaffee is preparing to push Mal var, the insurgent chief, in Southern Lu zon. He has ordered the transfer of the Fifth Infantry from Northern Luzon to Batangas province. Gen. Chaffee has not formulated plans for the occupation of the Island of Min doro. Gen. Hughes, at his request, wilt be permitted to continue in command of the Visayas Islands until the Samar cam paign is completed. Consequently, Gen. Davis will continue, temporarily, to be provost marshal at Manila. A detachment of the Fourth Infantry, scouting on a volcano island in Lake Taal, has captured Gonzalez, an insur gent leader, his adjutant, and several others. Bills have been passed establishing a board of health for the Philippines, and providing for laboratories in connection therewith. Gen. Chaffees staff appointees are as follows Adjutant general. Col. William P. Hall quartermaster general, Brj - Gen. Charles F. Humphrey inspector general, l.ieut.-Col. Joseph P. Sanger, and military secretary, Capt. Grote Hutcheson, Sixth Cavalry. Four American prisoners who escaped from Calapan, Mindoro, June 25 in a sailboat, have been recaptured. Several insurgent officers and 350 bolo- men have voluntarily taken the oath of allegiance at Cuino, province of B?taan. Capt. document.text: The October term of the circuit court of Appomattox county, with Judge Robert F. Hutcheson presid ing, will convene here Monday, at 10 A.M . The probability is that there will be only three indictments, and that the matters to come before the court can be disposed of in two days. Nevertheless the usual large attendance at court sessions here is expected. For the first time in a decade, prisoners confined in the county jail made good an escape last week-end. Three negro prisoners opened a hole in the brick wall opposite their se cond flood cells early Friday morn ing and lowered themselves down a blanket-ladder to freedom. They pried the bricks loose during the night, without awakening a fourth prisoner in the same cell. Saturday afternoon one of the ea-

document.text: The Hixburg Presbyterian Church and the Mathews Baptist Church will observe the Sesquicentennial of old Mathews Church, which was a union church from which both of these churches came. Chaplain Richard S. Hutcheson, Moderator of the West Hanover Presbytery, will preach at the Hix burg Presbyterian Church on Sun day, August 31, at 1030 oclock. The historical background of these churches will be of interest throughout the state, to many who once lived here or whose ancestors worshipped in that church. At the time a Sabbath School was organized, this portion of Ap pomattox was a part of Prince Ed- ,vard County, and the records there show that later a lot of about two acres was given by Dr. J. Walker on which a Union Church was to be built. This was to be used by any denomination-, ---Sstestant or Catho- lie. On the grounds oaks were planted by twos to form a W. Some of these are still there. At the time of the War Between the States, Capt. William Mathews, a veteran of the War of 1812, own ed the farm surrounding the church. When General U. S. Grant and his army passed through the farm, Capt. Mathews, to retard Grants progress to Appomattox, invited him to spend the night in the Mathews home. General Grant declined, and Capt. Mathews replied, You will come back from Appomattox faster than you went up there. The next day, Gen. Grant stopped along the same red clay road, and told Capt. Mathews that he knew Lee was going to surrender when he went up there. The little church, with a plank nailed down the middle to separate the ladies from ths gentleman, was near the road, but the Northern soldiers did it no harm. In the grove where once was the Union Church now stands the Hix burg Presbyterian Church. On an adjoining lot is Mathews Baptist Church.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. document.text: Seottsville,The wedding of Miss Billie Jane Burcher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lewis Burcher of Howardsville, and Edward Grady Covington, Jr., son of Mrs. C. C. Buie of Jackson, Miss and E. G. Covington, of Summer Hill, Albe marle County, was solemnized in the Seottsville Presbyterian Church at 330 oclock Sunday, June 3. The bride entered the church with her father, who gave her in mar riage. She wore an afternoon dress of white embroidered marquisette over white taffeta. She carried a white prayer book topped with a white orchid. Miss Nancy Peters, of Howards ville was the only attendant of the bride. E, G. Covington was his sons best man. The double ring cere mony was performed by the Rev. R. G. Hutcheson, pastor of the Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Rev. Jack B. Taylor, of the Methodist Church. Mr. and Mrs. Covington left Sun day night for a Southern wedding trip, which will take them to visit his mother in Jackson, Miss.

document.text: Richmond, Va., April 30.- Rural Virginia does not realize the ser iousness of the world war situation as it affects America, the State De fense Council was told By Dr. John R. Hutcheson, director of the VPi Extension School and chairman of the Radford regional defense coun cil.I know our country people, Mr. Hutcheson said. Our most pressing problem now it to get them to un derstand the seriousness of the issues confronting America.  Having accomplished many initial defense tasks, the State Council and regional councils are now asking where do we go from here,  Gov ernor Price was informed. General James A. Anderson, State Defense co-ordinator, said the army should guard railroad bridges and prevent sabotage, or ask the State to _ as sume this protective role. Washing ton will tell us, or we must tell them, General Anderson said. Asked by Governor Price what the General Assembly could do to extend public health service in the State, Dr. I. C. Riggin, State Health Commissioner, declared the most constructive step would be to provide county health units in the 52 counties not now rendering this essential function. Dr. Douglas S. Freeman, State Council chairman, emphasized that America is the only ?.ee _ nation able to furnish arms to resist world agressors. Defense activities at this stag would be diverted, General Ander son said, by building air-raid shel ters and evolving civilian evacua tio nplans. Immediate problems, he said, concern access highways, housing, machine tool inventories, public health a!t concentration points and soidier-sailor recreation. A review of Virginia defense act ivities in the past year shows the. following highlights

document.text: R. B. Hudgins, Appomattox Coun ty Agent since the spring of 1926, will retire March 31, according to announcement made this week. The veteran agricultural leader will be succeeded here by James A. Smith, a native of South Carolina and a graduate of Clemson College. Mr. Smith, 29, is at present assistant agent in Halifax County. He is a veteran of World War II, and dur ing his work with the Extension Service has won recognition for his activities with 4-H Clubs, as well as general assistance to farmers. The retirement of Mr. Hudgins will be made the occasion for a testimonial banquet, scheduled for Thursday night, March 10. Leaders of the V. f. I. Extension Service will join with local farmers and business men in honoring Mr. Hud gins. The banquet, scheduled for the school cafeteria, will include among its distinguished guests Dr. John R. Hutcheson, of V. P. I., and Judge Edwin W. Hudgins, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Virginia. He is a brother of R. B. Hudgins. The banquet is being arranged by the County Agricultural Board. Rueben Boatwright Hudgins is a native of New Canton, Bucking ham County. He attended Fork Un ion Military Academy and attended Virginia Polytechnic Institute. He served with the old Tri-State Tobacco Growers Association from 1922 until 1926. He is a Mason, a member of Liberty Baptist Church, and has received many honors dur ing his career in Extension work. Extension work began in Appo mattox in 1911. Major J. W. Flood was the first county agent and served from 1911 to 1913. Major Flood used horseback and a buggy to cover the county preaching the theory that a program and lime apd legumes would increase yields and make profits for farmers. His per sonality was an inspiration to farm ers and Major Flood declared that we could produce more corn and other crops on farmland by using smart methods.  In 1914, Bernard G. Anderson became the Appomattox County A- gent. He was the first agent ap pointed under the Smith-Lever Act. He was a 1906 graduate at V. P. I., and had served as assistant at the V. P. I. Experiment Station under E. H. Mathinson. He served as the county agent here until 1918, and is affectionately respected by every citizen of the county for his long career in farm, school and church activities. Mr. Anderson is now re tired and resides at his home here. W. H. Byrne succedded Anderson as county agent, iq 1918. He serv ed for even years. He was not above taking the handles of a plow to show farmers how to use the ridge system of cultivating tobacco and corn. He worked day and night showing farmers how to mix fertili zers, and better their ways of do ing things.. And then from his of fice he directed a variety of activi ties, such as 4-H Clubs. All the while he preached the worthwhile ness of Extension Service to farm ers. His efforts attracted wide at tention and he moved up in promo tion in 1926. Continued on Page Eight

document.text: Prepared by the United States Department of Agriculture. Wakefield farm, Westmoreland coon- ty, Virginia, has been enrolled In the Better Slres-Better Stock movement conducted by the various states and the United States Department of Agri culture. This Is the farm where George Washington was born In 1732, and the present occupants, Latane Brothers, come from straight Washing ton stock. It Is noteworthy that pure bred sires of good quality are hence forth to be used for all classes of live stock raised on this farm which Is fa mous as the birthplace of the Father of His Country. The stock on the his toric estate include cattle, horses, swine, sheep and poultry. All sires are now purebred the females are purebred, crossbred, and grade, and are to be gradually improved. County Agent L. M. Walker, Jr., In terested Latane Brothers In the na tionwide movement for Improved live stock, and John It. Hutcheson, director of extension for Virginia, regards the enrollment as of particular inter est since George Washington was a good farmer and a lover of good stock.

document.text: PLANNING NOW FOR VA. FAIR THIS FALL Richmond,- Va., July 1.- Eight members of the Agricultural Advis ory Committee of the Atlantic Ru ral Exposition headed by Dr. John R. Hutcheson, chancellor of V. P. I.i met with the executive committee of the State Fair here and outlined a program to extend the usefulness of the Exposition to the rural popula tion of Virginia, R. O. Glover, execu tive vice president said today. The committee, representing the major organized farm groups, will seek to stimulate more and better exhibits by men, women, boys and girls from all parts of the state will stimulate local press and radio coverage of participants in the fair, and will outline the aims and pur poses of the fair to all affiliated groups.

document.text: nesday, October 10, were announ ced today by R. B. Hudgins, coun ty agent, in the following state ment  The Appomattox Lions Club in cooperation with the Coble Dairy Products Company, cordial ly invites you to Appomattox Wed nesday, October 10.  We believe we have arranged a day you will enjoy and that you will profitt from it. It will be a Dairy Day in honor of you who have made a real contribution to dairy development in this area. To begin with, we have plan ned an Open House at the Coble Dairy Plant from j00 A. M. un til 1130 A. M. We want you to see how your milk is handled and to get acquainted with the folks at the plant. .  At 1130 we wilt all meet up at the court house grounds for a short program of value. Cash and merchandise prizes will be award ed to various patrons. Following the awarding of prizes there will be a program consisting of speech of welcome by Mayor Charles F. James, addresses by State Com missioner of Agriculture L. M. Walker, by Dr. T. B. Hutcheson, State Agronomist from V. P. 1., and George S. Coble of tne Coble Dairy Products Company. VEach family is requested to bring a basket lunch. Tables will be provided for this purpose. The Coble Dairy Products will furnish ice cream for your dinner, sobring your basket and mingle with your neighbors and get better acquaint ed with the farmers and business men who are interested in dairy development in this section.  At two oclock the big event will start, which 1 b a sale of Reg istered Guernsey bulls and heifers sponsored by the Virginia Agricul tural Service, Appomattox Lions Club, Appomattox County Agricul tural Board and the Coble Dairy Products Company. These animals have been select ed from the best Guernsey herds of the state and are from extreme ly high producing blood lines.This is a wonderful opportunity to get a real dairy sire or a heifer for foundation purposes.  We sincerely hope you will come and bring your family and enjoy a day getting better ac quainted with those interested in the dairy business, hear a real program from outstanding dairy leaders, and attend a sale where you would have an opportunity to purchase splendid registered Guern seys at youwown price.

document.text: More has been said during the past few years on the far mer relation to present econo mic conditions t h a n on any other one subject perhaps, and plan after plan has been made to give him the helping hand he needs, but talk and plinaa- like have gone the .way of th wind, and the farmer remains in straits which promise to be come more desperate each year Legislation and all suggest ed aids at this time ha e done little or nothing for the fanner. And perhaps this is partly at least, the fault of the farmer himself. He has becoitfe suspi cious of all sources of aid be cause so many bave failed him He has reached th point where he holds back when he shoUU push forward. !v , f One of the outstanding so lutions of the farm problems which has been offered is the co-operative- The value o  this solution is apparent. It is the one means of. bringing the farnief as a producer into a group It is the one means o stalilreing fgrm prices .and production, fpg mi YK. During the four years to tobacco marketing association operated in this state, Virginia owers averaged a higher a théir tobacco crops than they mre in sgry year period in the pâst half eentuP ey with the perception of war prices,-John Hutcheson, of to extension division,. has stated after studing the figure. Yet the farmers of this sec tion show little interest in the co-operative. The,, business men of the county have willing ly boosted the co-op and shown more, interest in it than the farmer himself. A local business man whose sympathy is with toe fermera mad the statement the other day that thf farmer does no, tant to., be helped,.. In expla nation he Said, that he had voluntarily given several days of his time to getting members for the co-operative, and that he had found, a general idea among the farmers he ap proached that he was doim, th work for the profit he could make out Kf it , Until the farmer shakes off his attitude of defense and be gins to , help himself to th which others dr tryjm j . to throjw his way, his positadr will remain much the same.

Messrs. Clark and Richard Caldwel- left last Thursday for University of Richmond.  Miss Bloise Atwood leaves today for Hollins, vhere she will attend school. Mr, J. A. Burke left this morning for Greensboro, N. 0., where he will take special treatment. He will be absent some time, but his wife will look after his business here during his absence. Announcement is made in reductions on Ford motor ve hicles as follows Runabout, with starter 465, Touring car 510, Truck 545, Tractor 790. dee W. M. Hancock, Appomat tox, Va., The bright tobacco market opens in L ncbburg Thursday and we will not be able to say what the prices will be until after the sales. The indications are taat fair prices will be ob- tained for all grades of good tobacco. In this issue our readers will find the Financial Statement of Appomattox county, the first one to be published for years. The law requires that the state ment be published annually, but for some reason the proper officer has neglected to have it done. It is a valuable paper, one that every taxpayer should study and if found erroneous or excessive allowances and appropriations made of your money, steps should be taken to correct same. Keep the pa per for future reference. Quite a number of Appomat tox people attended Judge H un dleys court at Farmville yes terday the occasion being a habeas corpus proceeding by H. A. Odor to obtain possession of his 2 year old son, which is detained by his wife in Acco- . mac county. The Judge de- . cided that the baby was too i young to take from its mother. ! No other question was consid ered bv the Judge. Messrs. Hutcheson and Daughtery of Accomac, and S. L. Ferguson of Appomattox, appeared for defense and A. H. Clement for  plaintiff.

document.text: Memorial day was fittingly observed here on Monday, and owing to inclement weather services were held in Court housethe day being deferred in order to observe Jeff Davis Memorial. Dr. Franklin, of N. Y., an old citizen of Appomat tox made the address which was much enjoyed. The service was in charge oi the U. D. C. The graves at the cemetery were decorated and wreathed in flowers. Dinner was served and all enjoyed the service. A male quartetProf. G. O. Gordon. Don Moses, J. C. Caldwell and W. W. Scott furnished splendid music. Mrs. John W. Davis, ot Lynchburg, made an address Mrs. Virginia LeGrand gave the Unfurled Banner and Mrs. Susie Roberts, of Char lotte, C. H., gave several hum orous selections. The veterans of the e.ounty are as follows Chas. M. Cole man, George W. Cheatham. C. W. Caldwell, R. jE. Cald well, D. A. Christian,C. C. Ferguson, D. P. Ferguson, S. T. Marsh,F. B. Moore, S. N. Ransom, J. G. Whitaker, Mil- ton Isbel, and John A. O Brien. Most of these veter ans were absent some attend ing the reunion at Charlotte, N. C., and hence only three were present. Visitors attending from Charlotte Courthouse were Mr. and Mr. B. N. Hutcheson, Mrs. Frank Bedinger, Mrs. Lester, Mrs. S. W. Roberts. An annual roll call of veter ans should be held and a short memorial to each absentee should be read. The roster is getting thin and the Daugh ters are always glad to servo in glorifying and perpetuating deeds of our heroic soldiers.
